Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Solid State Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Benjamin Keitz from the University of Texas Austin and colleague C. Grant Willson have acquired a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer equipped with solid state capabilities. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as the study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the study of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the changing interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. The results from these NMR studies have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is located a general user facility managed by highly qualified scientists as an integral part of research, research training and teaching. The improved research infrastructure further enriches the research experience for economically disadvantaged and underrepresented minority students at the institution. It is used in collaborations with non-Ph.D.-granting universities in the Austin metropolitan area. Specifically, faculty engages with students at St. Edwards University and Huston-Tillotson University as part of existing UT-Austin outreach programs. Such collaborations facilitate the development of interactions where faculty and students from these universities visit UT-Austin to use the spectrometer. Overall, the solid state NMR spectromater improves UT-Austin's many successful diversity initiatives.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in: (a) gaining information on polymeric materials, (b) studying conjugated metallopolymers, (c) characterizing porous solids, (d) studying protein self-assembly in structured biomaterials, (e) enabling the design of surface-modified nanoparticles, (f) contributing to research in the geological sciences, and (g) helping prepare new pharmaceutical dosage forms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solid-state Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (SSNMR) spectroscopy is an important tool for characterizing materials at the molecular level. The overall goal of this proposal was to obtain a SSNMR spectrometer for use at the University of Texas at Austin (UT Austin), which previously lacked an instrument with these capabilities.  

Intellectual Merit: During the proposal project period, this instrument enabled the characterization of a variety of materials prepared by research groups across the UT Austin campus. Specifically, the SSNMR spectrometer was used to: (1) measure the properties of polymeric materials, (2) study protein self-assembly in the presence of synthetic materials, (3) develop new materials for use in lithium ion batteries, and (4) characterize new dosage forms of pharmaceuticals. In the first area, the SSNMR spectrometer was used to characterize polymers formed by bacteria. These polymers may have a range of applications in plastics, drug delivery, and batteries. In a second area, the SSNMR spectrometer was used to verify the surface functionalization of highly porous materials. These materials were used to study the self-assembly of proteins relevant to neurodegenerative disease, which may have implications in how these diseases are treated.  In a third area, the SSNMR spectrometer was used to characterize new inorganic materials for lithium ion batteries. These materials could eventually lead to batteries with improved storage, stability, and recharging time. In a final area, the SSNMR spectrometer was used to characterize new pharmaceutical formulations. These formulations could improve the delivery and efficacy of pharmaceuticals with poor water solubility. Overall, the SSNMR spectrometer has filled a critical instrument infrastructure gap at UT Austin and will provide an important characterization tool for research groups across campus for years to come.

Broader Impacts: The SSNMR spectrometer has enhanced the professional development of undergraduate and graduate students at UT Austin. Specifically, the spectrometer is located in a user facility that contains other spectrometers and is open to all students and postdoctoral researchers. As part of their training, these individuals learn the operating principles behind the instrument and how it can benefit their specific project. Moreover, due to the complexity of NMR spectroscopy and instrumentation, the training regimen has expanded student's knowledge in general technical areas. For example, undergraduate students operating the instrument learned about cryogenics, superconducting magnets, advanced electronics, and a variety of other technologically sophisticated components. For many of these researchers, the SSNMR spectrometer is their first exposure to an advanced piece of instrumentation. The SSNMR spectrometer has also helped broaden access to the research environment at UT Austin. Visiting undergraduate and high school researchers typically do not have NMR spectrometers at their home institution (e.g., a community college) or have older instruments with reduced performance. The use of the SSNMR spectrometer provided a real world demonstration of techniques discussed in their undergraduate curriculum and also showed how the principles of NMR spectroscopy can be extended to solid-state materials. Overall, the SSNMR spectrometer will remain accessible to a diverse researcher pool and continue to expand student's knowledge in general technical areas.
